content: this week's video is a little bit different and a whole lot special hey
guys welcome back to black magic crafts I am really happy to be back with you
this week after having to cancel last week's episode due to a family emergency
and that situation bled into my production time for this week's video as
well so I was unable to craft anything for it but I decided to do something
kind of different I reached out to a whole bunch of my friends and fellow
content creators and asked them to give me a clip sharing one simple hobby tip
to make your hobby life a little bit easier and a whole bunch of them were
able to accommodate and get back to me and send something and not everyone
could I was really short and noticed so no hard feelings to those of you who
couldn't make it happen yeah I guess this is gonna be some sort of hobby
channel mega show so without further ado let's get to our first clip what a black
magic crafters I want to show you guys two tricks that you can do with thin
plastic cement a lot of times I'm scraping off mould lines I get a lot of
plastic shavings in areas that are difficult to deal with depending on the
amount it really eats a solution to get rid of them all is to hit it with a
little bit of thin plastic cement this will melt down the shavings to almost
nothing another fun trick is to help you deal
with gaps in plastic models if the part is right I often clamp my models
together with a small spring clamp this causes a little bead of plastic to form
at the seam sand this back when it's dry and you have a perfectly flush
connection but what if there's still a gap there like here where I slashed a
hole in the model while removing it from the sprue toss a few chunks of sprue
inside a bottle of old plastic cement and then wait it'll melt the plastic and
turn it into a thicker substance the ratio of cement to plastic sprue is
undetermined just add a little by little until the consistency is right this
combination is often called sprue goo and can be used to fill the gaps on
plastic models you apply a little goo and then if needed you can smooth it out
with some thin plastic cement thanks for letting me invade your channel Jeremy
now out of the next tip one morning a warm well
come from Hamburg Germany usually you know my craft videos only in German but
Jeremy asked me if I could contribute my favorite crafting tip for this video in
English of course Jeremy with pleasure the tabletop workshop has been on
YouTube for more than 5 years and there's one important thing I've noticed
ever since so my number one tip to you is leave your comfort zone from time to
time and try something new no matter if it's a new tool a new material new
colors are completely new crafting technique just take a new path from time
to time to automatically develop new skills and prove yourself some great
painted miniatures simply require new approaches primer base colors wash and
dry brushing are great but sometimes glazes or oil paints give a model that
extras something terrain can be created with a base color and dry brushing
without a question but using washes for example that are
applied wet on wet on the base color it looks much more interesting doesn't it
it's best to try out everything new in small steps to gain experience if you
then like the new material or technique start bigger projects always step by
step so as not to overwhelm yourself therefore just try something new just
grab a tutorial now that you thought it was too difficult or complex and with
all this in mind have fun painting crafting and discovering new skills hey
black magic crafts Ian's something Jeremy mentioned that might be a value
to you guys is how I approach projects I think it would be fairly true
objectively to say that I get stuff done so my tip would be to think both macro
and micro at the same time big and small big projects are really important
because they stretch yourself the things you learn along the way of really biting
off more than you can chew and really just taking your time to chew through it
until it's done can be monumental so big projects are really important at the
same time it can be too much sometimes and really hard to finish which is why
it's really important to break down your big projects or your big goals or
creative ideas into micro sections if I am making an animation which I did a
couple years ago I made something called the towel teller which took me 10 months
to do and if I looking at how much I had to finish as a
whole I would have given up but because I was so focused on one Scene at a time
every day I had one scene to do I was doing one shot that's it that's all I
was focused on break it down into lots of little projects that you can look at
finishing each part and feel proud of and give yourself that gratification
along the way to keep you moving and then on the micro end to avoid yourself
burning out on the big projects sometimes it's good to step away and do
something micro that feeds your creativity it might be a hobby on the
side it might be music it might be some other small project or a commission that
builds you back up so that you can empty your creativity back into the big thing
you're working on so that's the main thing also scheduling at my laziest as a
young adult when I wanted to get to work on projects but stroll to wake up in the
morning I would have a bath at 8 a.m. and I would wake up at 9 a.m. and a cold
bar fully awake and ready to get to work so sometimes requires a little bit of
discipline and just getting stuff done that's some of the stuff that I have to

wait wait a minute oh I bet see he meant a crafting tip not oh this crafting tip
is all about priming found objects in my crafting I work with a lot of old toys
the easiest way to figure out how to prime a toy is the rigidity for example
this McDonald's toy is made out of very stiff plastic and thus a spray primer
will probably work pretty well on it and of course you don't have to use army
painter on something like this you can just buy the cheapest all surface primer
you can find some plastics will require you to sand down the material a little
bit before you can get good adhesion with a spray primer but other pieces
like this castle were spray primed without any special preparation at all
sometimes just rust Thursday in some cases you're going to want to utilize
a more rubbery toy in these cases you're probably going to make use of acrylic a
polyurethane primer vallejo surface primer is my favorite brand it was
originally made for airbrushing but it's thick enough to be applied with a
paintbrush badger also makes a line of polyurethane primer but it's much
thinner than the Vallejo if you have plastic that's very glossy and difficult
to prime you might want to try out Vallejo mekka primer it was specifically
designed to adhere to difficult surfaces and a lot of people that like to paint
transformer toys really like this stuff and of course for me personally there's
some projects where I don't bother priming the toys at all when considering
these translucent rats for example all I did was wash them in very thin coats of
paint and there's still that color years later so the next time you find an old
toy I hope you think to yourself hey that could be the centerpiece for my
next crafting project eggs over easy eggs over hard now one of the things I
wanted to share is pushing your boundaries and failing and being okay
with that I know Jeremy did an awesome video already on failure and you know
and how important that actually is to the Hobby how you how you don't want get
ahead unless you push yourself so take a look at this wizard tower I made this
wizard tower tower here I'm really proud of it I had to redo this resin base I
bought three made yeah three times and now it's a whopping and pounds look at
that thing that's ridiculous but you can see all the layers of resin and that's
basically me just covering up my mistakes
I made this big massive wave in the front there and actually that didn't
work out quite as well off the bat as I wanted to I had to take the angle
grinder the to that thing and hack the waves out and I think that's a big key
thing to take away that I've taken away is not being afraid to mess up and push
your boundaries so you could be really comfortable with the technique you got
that technique down but you're just kind of afraid to push it to that next level
to try something a little more complex maybe or just a different and you're
afraid if you do once you normally do you're just gonna
wreck whatever it is you're working on which sucks but you know honestly I
think that's an important thing to do if you want to push yourself sooner we want
to grow we got to just take that chance try this thing that has the chance of
wrecking whatever it is that you do but it also has a chance of pushing you up
to that next level so there you go so thanks again Jeremy for having me on

to do with the glue gun another bonus so this is it dries hard
but it's also a little bit flexible so it won't easily break or crack like some
other materials another great use for this material is kind of doing sculpting
where you don't need to sculpt so instead of sculpting on my purple worm
and having all these folds of skin I use the modeling paste and like I said ran

I'm email from squid Mar miniatures and today I'm bringing you a few hot tips
that I don't think Jeremy actually covered on this channel as a miniature
painter and the aroma builder I often use a lot of natural materials and
Jeremy uses XPS foam and things like that to build stuff I tend to go to the
naturals like roots and coconut fiber and dirt
and sand and now that it's spring and you're out in the woods walking or maybe
you're just doing gardening work look for fallen trees or roots of bushes that
you removed from your garden and these roots can be perfect for many different
things on your diorama builds or your table builds or whatever you're gonna
use it for I use roots and place them like trees or climbing vines on
different buildings that I built or printed I used to mess trees on the
arama builds or just as cool roots on the ground if they're small enough just
make sure to let them dry and clean them up before you use them another hot tip
is one of my absolute favorite basing materials and that is coconut fiber you
buy these in bigger larger dried bricks on
dollar stores or IKEA here in Sweden we have them actually and when you grind
them down to smaller pieces you can get these slightly larger bits that you can
use as ground floor or ground covering for forest terrain or these super time
superfine ones that can work as sand it looks really good really natural you get
these fine coconut hairs that also look as roots or different grass strands
that's just sticking out from the ground and as a final tip for all of those of
you who live in a place where you have birches in the fall these different seed
pods that hangs up the tree dry up and if you go and pick them up from the tree
you can pick these like larger bits and they fall apart instantly and all these
small pieces that you get look pretty much exactly like a dry leaf so if
you're doing something in the woods like a D&D table that has wood parts or maybe
it's a cave entrance and you want to have dead leaves that have blown in on
the ground of the cave these small birch seeds or whatever they
are are amazing as a sort of natural replacement for leaves about an egg

everybody Jim the table top engineer here let me show you how to make a mini
sci-fi display diorama in under one hour complete with LED lighting effect I
started off by getting a small frame and removing the glass and backing I created
a template that you can find in the description below I trace that on a
chipboard cut it out scored the edges and folded it up this makes like a
little hollow box it will fit in the back of the picture frame tape up the
edges and go find your bits box I just ended up taking a bunch of junk bits
from my junk bin some of these are sprue pieces I just cut them glue them in
there they look very sci-fi ish make sure to get the edges too that adds to
the effect and then add some pipes and stuff like that I added a little panel
or a doorway just for a little extra detail paint it up in a light grey or
something that will make your mini really pop out
next I made a little machine almost like a computer it'll have a screen on it
that an LED will fit inside go ahead and glue your glue the machine closed I cut
it with some angled pieces to kind of give the screen an angled look next I
went back into my bits box and I glued some metal electronics pieces just for
extra detail I had a little plastic bulb that I filled with water and green food
coloring about halfway and I used a plastic glue to secure it to one of the
sprue pieces just a little act extra visual effect I cut a hole in the bottom
of the thing where the machine would go over this is where the LED will be
inserted painted the machine white went back and painted some of the wall bed
silver I cut a piece of opaque plastic from a lid that will sort of dull the
brightness of the LED inside glue it over the machine put a little cover over
it and then I added some bits and pieces and paint it up the machine glued the
machine over the hole then I added a little hinge with a piece of painters
tape on one side and velcro on the other to secure it this will all be a little
LED bulb inside so it doesn't fall out and here you go a little sci-fi diorama
with a lighting effect you could leave the machine out and you'd have room for

one of the most important things you should realize about black magic craft
is that this is not a channel about how to make things or what to make this is
about why you should be making them and this is the thing that most people miss
Jeremy tells a good story about why he's doing the things that he's doing and I
want to impart this to you so that you can understand that if you are one of
the people who likes to watch but doesn't
actually create anything ya have to make the things that are being shown on those
videos you have to do the things that Jeremy is doing what's extremely
important is one that you start creating and two that you come up with something
that you want that you feel passionate about because it has a very important
effect on you having a purpose something to do something to create it's very good
for your mental health it's very good for family relationships if you build
things together it's very good for building friendships it's very good for
all these extra benefits that are never really mentioned we're in the tabletop
crafts guild kit tons and tons of email from people about how we've helped them
have a better relationship with their kids
you know people and their spouses are getting a long bachelor because they're
